These appear here to avoid circular dependencies in that project plus these are needed by everybody. When a session is authenticated, instances of the concrete classes are assigned to the causality.

member.name: T:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Log
member.summary: This class provides static methods to write to the default logging instance.

member.name: M:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Logging.LogEntry(Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.LogLevel,System.Object)
member.summary: Logs the message to the current log at the specified logging level (unless it is masked). Note that I allow you to pass in an object instead of just a string. This allows me to defer doing the ToString() of an object to just before plopping it in the logging queue (which will happen in this call, unless the log level is masked). In this way, you can easily pass in an object to dump it, but the string representation will not be constructed unless this log line will appear in the final log.

member.name: M:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Logging.LogToEventLog(System.String,System.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType)
member.summary: Places the event description in the application event log. This is the same as using Logging.Log with a log level at or above the event log level except that this call will always write to the event log regardless of the log level and it will happen immediately rather than queue up the write.

member.name: P:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Logging.Enabled
member.summary: Returns true if the logging is enabled. This can be useful from the outside if you have to calculate something for the debug log, but don't want to waste the time if logging is off.

member.name: P:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Logging.ApplicationName
member.summary: Returns the application name. This is the name used for the NCC configuration settings. If the name is not set at the time of the first get, we consult the app.config file for the "Application.Name" key. Should that key not exist, we use the default name.

member.name: T:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.ProtocolMessages.UDEventID
member.summary: These user-data event IDs originate in the platform for CrossCheck devices. TrimTracs effectively use two ID numbers assigned to CrossCheck events mostly to make as much common as possible between the two message hierarchies. The artificial IDs do exist between the two platforms for the sake of a common realtime feed.

member.name: T:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.ProtocolMessages.IXmlEventFragment
member.summary: Classes implementing IXmlEventFragment are available to the event feed. IHighLevelPlatformEvent is a superset interface that includes the packet and event times. This interface is mostly used by user-data messages (duh) to implement what is needed to publish a -portion- of the XML event. For example, the user-data tracker messages implement the interface and use XmlEvent to publish the properties of the user-data high-level message then defer to the user-data message to publish its specific properties. It is left to something outside the PlatformMessages hierarchy to generate the event envelope with the event and packet GMTs (since that isn't available to the messages). The IHighLevelPlatformEvent interface includes methods for publishing a full event including the times. Clients to the PlatformEvents classes receive arrays of IHighLevelPlatformEvent.

member.name: M:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.ProtocolMessages.IXmlEventFragment.XmlEvent(System.Xml.XmlWriter,System.Int32)
member.summary: Method creates the XML for the platform's real-time event feed.
member.param: The writer used to generate the event XML.
Version of the event XML to create. 1.0 is the legacy realtime with all its special cases; 2.0 is a format that's easier to deserialize.

member.name: P:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.ProtocolMessages.IXmlEventFragment.EventIsPublished
member.summary: Returns true if the event associated with the platform message is published. Sometimes a platform message has an associated event, but whether it is published or not depends on values in the particular instance. Further, we have in the past needed to mute certain messages based on the messaging version we want to maintain (which we can do through the config file).

member.name: P:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.ProtocolMessages.IXmlEventFragment.EventID
member.summary: Returns the platform event ID number for the message. Note that this ID number is often dependent on the values in the message.

member.name: P:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.ProtocolMessages.ICsvValues.CsvValues
member.summary: Returns the CSV (comma-separated values) string containing the parsed event data typically used for reports. It is stored in NCCDB.Outgoing_Event_Msg.Data_Value for reports to access, however guerrilla IO needs it as well for backward compatibility.

member.name: T:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.ProtocolMessages.IHighLevelPlatformEvent
member.summary: A HighLevelPlatformEvent is a wrapper to a realtime event XML fragment. This wrapper includes the items that don't appear in a single platform message (for example, the message contains the data from the tracker, but the timestamps associated with it are external to the message as well as the owner ID of who owns the message.

member.summary: Overloaded onstructor.
member.param: This field will be blank when an address object is returned by the method. However, when using the method, this property can be used as a means to associate items in the coordinates array that is passed in with items in the address array that is returned. For example, if you pass in a coordinate array and one of the coordinate objects has an ID of "firstCoord", the reverse geocoded address can be found in the resulting address array by finding the address object with an ID of "firstCoord". See the Html example of the method for more information.
The house or street number portion of an address.
The street number and name portion of an address.
The city name portion of an address.
The state/province name or abbreviation portion of an address.
The zip code portion of an address.

member.name: F:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Objects.HarvesterReturnTypes.HarvesterResult.IsReplayBlock
member.summary: True when the block of events was previously sent to the client, but either negatively acknowledged or the acknowledgement timeout expired. Currently this timeout is 10 minutes.

member.name: F:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Objects.HarvesterReturnTypes.HarvesterResult.MorePending
member.summary: Normally, clients poll the method periodically, perhaps every 15 seconds. When this field is true, then the client should call back immediately rather than waiting for the next polling interval since there seems to be more data waiting.

member.name: F:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Objects.HarvesterReturnTypes.HarvesterResult.EndDateRangeGmt
member.summary: The end of the date range considered for this block. When exact value may not match between when the block is first handed back to the client and when the block is returned as part of a replay. Use this value to assist in putting up a progress bar when doing long harvests from the past. Effectively if you are doing a long backfill harvest from A to B, you could adjust the progress bar to the position represented by this date (you should keep track of the maximum value you've ever received for this date and use it, however, to keep retries from moving your progress bar backwards).

member.summary: The organization ID for which the driver belongs to.

member.summary: A unique string per organization that the user enters in order to login.
member.exception: Thrown if the length of the string exceeds 64 characters.
member.remarks:
Required: The maximum allowed length is 64 characters and the minimum allowed length is one character.
Must be unique per organization.

member.name: P:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Objects.User.Password
member.summary: The user's password. Write only.
member.remarks:
When creating a user, this property must contain a non empty string. However, since this property is write only, the user's password is not known after creation. Therefore, when modifying a user, this field can be set to null to prevent the password from being changed inadvertently. Setting the password to an empty string will cause an error and setting it to any other valid string will effectively change the user's password.
The maximum allowed length is 64 characters and the minimum allowed length is four characters.

member.name: T:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Objects.UserProfile
member.summary: The UserProfile inherits from User and adds Organizations and Capabilities. The object is used by the UserWS web service and the TrimView client. In the case of the TrimView client, it is used to combine the retrieval of user, organization, and capability data in order to increase the speed of the initial view load sequence. Formerly, two web service calls were made by TrimView for every user to retrieve organization, and capability data.

member.name: T:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: A TrimbleException adds nothing to the ApplicationException. We use it so the client can distinguish between an exception thrown by the Trimble platform versus an infrastructure error (e.g., transport error, marshaling error, etc.) Those clients who don't care to distinguish can simply catch the ApplicationException common base.
member.remarks:
When working with the web services, errors are reported through SOAP exceptions. Receiving an exception indicates that the web method was unable to complete. The content of the exception includes a category for the exception along with an English description of the failure.
The <detail> element contains the full name of the exception class thrown. (While the name of the exception is included in the .NET platfor generated <faultstring> element, it is difficult to extract reliably. Integration should use the <detail> element to programmatically inspect the exception (as opposed to matching the English description). Trimble exceptions follow this format:
Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.<exceptionCategory>, where exceptionCategory is the name of the exception class thrown and indicates the error. Other exception are possible (e.g. System.OutOfMemoryException) and are returned with their full name in the <detail> element.
Note that all SOAP exceptions are wrapped in a <soap:Fault> element. Successful results appear in a <soap:Envelope> element.

member.name: T:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.TrimbleException
member.summary: A generic exception thrown by the Trimble Platform.
member.remarks:
For information on what caused the exception, view the exception's Message property.
When making SOAP requests, the exception type name will be available in the <detail> node of the Soap Fault response. The first line of the <string> node in a Soap Fault response will be equivalent to the Message property. This node will also contain the Xml of the original request on line two.

member.name: T:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.TmsQueueSynchronized
member.summary: This is a naive implementation that models a Queue.Synchronized(new Queue()) with the addition of Push and Pop methods. I developed this for the harvester's fulfilment thread so I could queue up work items, but push high-priority items such as the realtime pull query.

member.name: M:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.TmsQueueSynchronized.Dequeue
member.summary: Dequeues an item from the head of the queue; if there are no items, throws a InvalidOperationException exception.

member.name: M:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.TmsQueueSynchronized.Enqueue(System.Object)
member.summary: Places the item at the end of the list.

member.name: M:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.TmsQueueSynchronized.Push(System.Object)
member.summary: Pushes the item to the front of the list; next dequeue operation will get this item.

member.name: M:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.TmsQueueSynchronized.Pop
member.summary: Pops an item off the end of the queue. This gets the item from the opposite end as the Dequeue operation. The last item Enqueued will be popped off with this operation.

member.summary: Computes and returns the CRC-8 value for the given string of bytes. If you call this method with raw data to send, you get back the CRC value to append to the data. If you pass in the raw data packet with the CRC byte at the end, you'll get a zero back if the CRC passed.

member.name: F:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Utility.MacIdRegex
member.summary: This method compares the input string against common Mac-48 or EUI-64 mac address string formats Example: 94:E0:EE:0A:4F:F7 or 00:0C:29:FF:FE:0C:47:D5

member.name: F:Trimble.Platform.CommonLibrary.Utility.LicenseKeyRegex
member.summary:
This method compares the input string against valid GUID string formats as well as Trimfleet Android license internal format.
Note that the internal license string format presently is formed from 8 pairs of 4 digits, each separated by hyphen. This is not a valid GUID string format according to Microsoft
CommonLibrary targets .NET 3.5 otherwise we could use Guid.TryParse as introduced in .NET 4.0 Most of the GUID regex were sourced from http://geekswithblogs.net/colinbo/archive/2006/01/18/66307.aspx
